G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as it is a civil action in which the amount in controversy exceeds the jurisdictional minimum of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the cause of action arose in Springfield, Massachusetts, within this County.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid acts or omissions that could foreseeably cause injury to others.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The court expressly states, as a general principle of Massachusetts tort law, that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, citing prior Massachusetts precedent and the Restatement. It then applies that general duty framework, conditioned on foreseeability, to recognize a duty of reasonable care in the particular circumstances of negligent firearm storage. This directly aligns with the claimed proposition about a general duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable injury to others.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.”

Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729 (2000).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid acts or omissions that could foreseeably cause injury to others.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion does not articulate a general, free‑standing duty that "every person" must exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable injury to others. Instead, it analyzes duty in the specific context of landowners and social hosts, and ultimately emphasizes limits on any duty to protect against third‑party conduct absent a special relationship or creation/control of the risk. The court even quotes a concurrence stating that no person owes a duty to prevent harm from a situation he or she did not create, which undercuts the broad proposition asserted.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729 (2000).relevant_excerpt: We think the Flanagan case was correctly decided, not necessarily because alcohol and fireworks are comparable, but because the common bond between the decisions involving social host liability for alcohol-related injuries, and the circumstances here, is the fact that the defendants did not provide the harmful item, did not control its use, and did not create the situation that caused the danger. See Cremins v. Clancy, supra at 296 (O’Connor, J., concurring) (“no person owes to another a duty to prevent the harmful consequences of a condition or situation he or she did not create”).

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to properly secure or safely store personal property (the ladder) on a shared driveway where it posed a known and foreseeable risk of harm.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion does not establish that the defendant owed a duty to secure or safely store personal property such as a ladder on a shared driveway. The case involves scaffolding collapse during roofing work and focuses on lack of evidence of causation and on whether the homeowner/general contractor owed any duty to the worker-plaintiffs; the court explicitly declines to decide the duty question and never discusses any duty to secure property on a driveway. Thus, it does not support the specific duty proposition stated.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.”

Gamache v. Mayor of North Adams, 17 Mass.raw_text: Gamache v. Mayor of North Adams, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 291 (1983)
Gamache v. Mayor of North Adams, 17 Mass.proposition: Defendant breached his duty of care by allowing the ladder to remain unsecured in a location susceptible to wind and in proximity to Plaintiff’s vehicle in a condition that could foreseeably result in property damage.
Gamache v. Mayor of North Adams, 17 Mass.case_name: Gamache v. Mayor of North Adams
Gamache v. Mayor of North Adams, 17 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns civil service employment rights, waiver, estoppel, and summary judgment procedure; it does not involve negligence, duty of care, unsecured ladders, wind, or property damage. Nothing in the case discusses standards for securing objects near vehicles or foreseeable risk of property damage, so it cannot support the cited negligence proposition.
Gamache v. Mayor of North Adams, 17 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In 1981 the city of North Adams (city) approved a plan of reorganization under which the police, fire and other city departments were replaced by a department of public safety… On May 19, 1981, the mayor of the city notified the plaintiff… that the position of chief of police which he then held was abolished by the plan… In the Superior Court the plaintiff sought a judgment ordering the mayor to reinstate him as a captain of police….”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of the March 15, 2023 incident and Plaintiff’s resulting property damage and financial losses.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The excerpt shows the court concluding that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence, i.e., that causation was lacking. The proposition claims the opposite—that defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of the incident and resulting losses. Thus, this case undercuts rather than supports the claimed causation proposition.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.raw_text: Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard College, 432 Mass. 107 (2000)
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.proposition: The harm Plaintiff suffered was foreseeable and within the scope of risk created by Defendant’s recognized inaction.
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.case_name: Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard College
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.support_reasoning: The case is an employment discrimination and retaliation decision focused on burden-shifting, pretext, jury instructions, and damages. It does not analyze duty, foreseeability, scope of risk, or harms resulting from a defendant’s recognized inaction in the tort sense. Nothing in the opinion frames the harm as a foreseeable consequence within the scope of risk created by Harvard’s inaction, so it does not provide authority for that specific negligence-style proposition.
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.relevant_excerpt:
There was sufficient evidence for the jury to find that the reason given by Harvard for terminating Abramian was not true, which alone would have warranted a finding for Abramian, as we discuss at Part 3(a), infra. 

The graphic evidence of discriminatory animus on the part of Dowling and Henaghan provides further support for a finding that Abramian was more likely than not the victim of unlawful discrimination.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s negligence constitutes actionable failure to exercise reasonable care under Massachusetts common law and G.L. c. 231, § 85, as Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care of an ordinarily prudent person in similar circumstances.

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Defendant’s negligence constitutes actionable failure to exercise reasonable care under Massachusetts common law and G.L. c. 231, § 85, as Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care of an ordinarily prudent person in similar circumstances.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The case does not hold that the defendant’s conduct constitutes actionable negligence under Massachusetts common law or G.L. c. 231, § 85. Instead, the SJC expressly concludes that, on these facts, the social host owed no common-law duty to the injured third party because he neither served nor provided alcohol and lacked control over the liquor supply. The opinion thus rejects, rather than supports, a negligence claim premised on failure to exercise reasonable care in these circumstances.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: “Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence… It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se… Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort.”

Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.raw_text: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342 (1983)
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.proposition: Plaintiff’s contributory negligence, if any, was less than that of Defendant under G.L. c. 231, § 85, and therefore does not bar recovery.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.case_name: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.support_reasoning: The case does discuss G.L. c. 231, § 85 and comparative negligence, but it does not hold or state that the plaintiff’s contributory negligence was less than the defendant’s and therefore does not bar recovery. Instead, the opinion addresses (1) the effect of employer negligence in a third‑party negligence action and (2) whether comparative negligence or contributory negligence principles apply to breach‑of‑warranty claims (they do not). The court’s general description of § 85’s operation is not applied to find that this particular plaintiff’s negligence was less than Firestone’s or that recovery is therefore allowed.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.relevant_excerpt: “If the injured employee is free from negligence, there is no reason to deny him full recovery. If he is not, his negligence can be accounted for directly by comparing it to the negligence of the third party in determining both the latter’s liability and damages. G. L. c. 231, § 85.”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: As a further basis for liability, Massachusetts premises liability law and negligence principles require owners or occupiers of property to act reasonably to avoid harm to foreseeable persons on adjacent property.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The case rejects, rather than affirms, any broad duty of an owner or occupier to protect foreseeable persons on adjacent public property. The SJC emphasizes that, although landowners must use their own land reasonably so as not to injure travelers on adjacent highways, they generally have no duty with respect to the safety of users of adjacent public roads and expressly declines to expand landowner liability in that direction. Thus it does not support the claimed proposition that Massachusetts law requires owners to act reasonably to avoid harm to foreseeable persons on adjacent property; it limits such a duty instead.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: “Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway. … The mere fact that Westwood’s facilities used land on both sides of Route 1A, without more, does not necessarily impose on it the broad duty to provide safe passage over the State highway… To hold that Westwood owed the plaintiff such a duty would significantly expand the scope of a landowner or possessor’s duties with respect to adjacent public roads… This we decline to do.”

Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.raw_text: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002)
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.proposition: As a further basis for liability, Massachusetts premises liability law and negligence principles require owners or occupiers of property to act reasonably to avoid harm to foreseeable persons on adjacent property.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion is about an employer’s duty (or lack thereof) regarding negligent hiring/supervision of an employee who later murdered a neighbor; it does not frame the issue as premises liability or a duty owed by a landowner to persons on adjacent property. The court ultimately holds that Titus & Bean owed no duty to the victim under the circumstances, and nowhere articulates a rule that owners/occupiers must act reasonably to avoid harm to foreseeable persons on neighboring property. Thus, it does not support the claimed Massachusetts premises-liability proposition.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Here, the motion judge ruled as matter of law that the defendant did not owe any duty to the victim… In sum, a background check would not have provided any additional information that would have enabled Titus & Bean to reasonably foresee that Kelley posed a threat to members of the public at or near 385R Court Street… As matter of law, Titus & Bean owed the victim no legal duty.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: As a further basis for liability, Massachusetts premises liability law and negligence principles require owners or occupiers of property to act reasonably to avoid harm to foreseeable persons on adjacent property.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurring opinion focused on the status-based distinctions among trespassers, licensees, and invitees. It does not address, much less establish, any duty owed by owners or occupiers to persons on adjacent property, nor does it discuss off‑premises or neighboring land injury scenarios. Without language on duties to persons on adjacent property, this case excerpt does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.
